title: Be able disable task detection from tasks.json or override tasks execution

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
Currently VSCode uses `tasks.json` to detect the tasks. If there is a `FileSystemProvider` registered, it will use it to read `tasks.json`. The problem with that is the tasks may not make sense if they come from something else other than `file:/.../.vscode/tasks.json`. E.g. if the file system provider is of a remote kind (like fetching files from sftp or Live Share), tasks from `tasks.json` most likely won't work locally.

To deal with this scenario, VSCode may provide different options:
1. An ability to override task execution for any tasks from `tasks.json`. This work may be merged into #33523. VSCode should pass along the URI of the original `tasks.json` to the extension code that overrides the task execution.
1.  An ability to disable tasks detection from `tasks.json` based on the file scheme. This will be a new API. Alternatively, you can make VSCode respect `tasks.json` only from `file:` scheme and let the extensions opt in other schemes if they so chose.

title: When using a variable-width font, line numbers should use tabular numbers
body: (This is obviously very low priority) When using a variable-width (i.e. non-monospaced) font, the line numbers look bad since e.g '1' is more narrow than '0'. With the CSS `font-variant-numeric: tabular-nums` all digits would be of equal width.

title: Checking for updates and installing extensions doesn't work behind corporate proxy
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.33.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VSCode.
2. Try to check for updates.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled? Yes

The error is `net::ERR_NAME_NOT_RESOLVED`.


This is basically the same as [this issue](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/32210).

Proxy-related environment variables are set, but VSCode seems to be ignoring them. Relevant settings such as `http.proxy` seem to be ignored too. The only way to make it work is to start VSCode from a terminal with the `--proxy-server` option.

Notes:

* other software (e.g. Firefox) works fine
* Except Chrome, which required the `--proxy-server` option too
* I tried to put the `--proxy-server` option in the .desktop launcher: works for Chrome, doesn't work for VSCode (very strange)

title: Upper-case aware completion when opening folder with remote ssh

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Hi,

When opening folders or files while using remote access through ssh with VS Code insiders (thanks, it is working fantastic and as expected),  text completion seems oblivious to upper-case when suggesting files. Let me show you with an example.

Let's say you want to open ./Axyz but . also contains folders abc.
What happens usually is that one would press "A" and then tab, expecting it to get completed as Axyz. Instead, VS Code Insiders puts the prompt over the first choice in alphabetical order, abc. Thus, doing "A"+TAB complets as /abc/.

It is counter-intuitive with every other text completion that I know, including Intellisense, could you please change that or add an option ?

It is clearly more a nice-to-have than a must have, as it saves max 2 key press by completion, but we are all lazy.

title: Improve handling of extensions when workspaceContains times out

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
I had an issue raised by a user that say my extension activate spawn its language server while they were working on an unrelated (non-Dart) project (https://github.com/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/issues/1699).

It turns out that there is a hard-coded timeout of 7 seconds for `workspaceContains` activation events and this user hit that (possibly through a combination or large folder, and machine being busy, other extensions loading, running emulators etc.):

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/b4cd3749542a0da6f9cf830d49fdc4bd9e9bc4f5/src/vs/workbench/api/node/extHostExtensionService.ts#L50

The behaviour when this timeout is hit is to pre-emptively activate the extensions in this case. I understand why this is done but it seems like it may trade one problem (searching the tree) for another (activating a bunch of unrelated extensions that may spawn language servers).

I think there should be more control (for users or extensions) over this behaviour, for example:

- Being able to configure the timeout
- Being able to change the behaviour of whether to load extensions when this happens (or be prompted and warned)
- Showing the activation reason in the "Show Running Extensions" section
- Allowing extensions to control whether to activate when workspaceContains times out (in my case, it's fine not to - workspaceContains is for convenience so the user doesn't need to open a `.dart` file before we activate, but if no Dart or pubspec.yaml was found in 7 seconds, it would be preferable to wait for the user to open one (or one be discovered in the tree) before activating)
- Telling the extension the activation reason (https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/44711)

Of course, the extension could scan the tree and not spawn the language server, but then it's just doing the work that VS Code specifically was trying to avoid, and if multiple extensions are all doing it, it'll be worse performing than if VS Code did it!

title: A snippet definition should not require a "prefix" property to be considered valid
body:
Snippets are typically for things we use often, but they are also useful for things we use less often, but all the same want to automate.

In those cases, it's not worth having to come up with a `prefix` (a.k.a `tabTrigger` in TextMate/Sublime parlance) for autocompletions purposes, because we can just use VSC's `Insert Snippet` command to find and insert those snippets.

Unfortunately, when defining snippets in a `.code-snippets` file, if we omit a `"prefix": "foo"` key/value, that snippet is considered invalid (gets a squiggly underline) and hence is not offered in the list shown by the `Insert Snippet` command.

Please make the `prefix` property optional.

REF: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/userdefinedsnippets

title: Git: Add events to API

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Hello.

I'm trying to create an extension that tracks when the user changes the branch. I've been reading past issues asking of the git API, and I've been able to get the current branch of the user. However, it does not seem to be a way to subscribe to an event on the repository changes.

It would be very useful being able to subscribe to events on commits, merges, or rebases, for example. I was thinking about a function `onBranchChange`, that accepts as a parameter a callback to be executed every time the event is fired. 

I tried using the [oficial API](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/tree/master/extensions/git), but you can't listen when git is enabled, so you can't start your extension from the startup. It does not listen to branch changes either, although it does listen to repository changes which it is even better for what I'm trying to accomplish.

Thank you.

title: Unable to debug a remote authority resolver extension
body: Issue Type: Bug Since updating VS Code Insiders sometime last week (sorry I don't know exactly which build), I've been unable to debug our remote authority resolver, using the same steps that had worked with builds prior to that. First, some background... We have a resolver extension for the "cloudenv" remote authority. It has the appropriate activation event declared in package.json: ``` "activationEvents": [ "onResolveRemoteAuthority:cloudenv" ], ``` And we register the resolver in the extension activate() function: ``` context.subscriptions.push( vscode.workspace.registerRemoteAuthorityResolver('cloudenv', resolver)); ``` This "Cloud Environments" resolver mostly works; in fact we demoed it at the build event. But not being able to debug it makes further development very difficult. I'm trying two approaches, both of which worked previously. 1. Launch VS Code with a remote URI specified directly in launch.json: ``` "name": "Launch Extension", "type": "extensionHost", "request": "launch", "runtimeExecutable": "${execPath}", "args": [ "--extensionDevelopmentPath=${workspaceRoot}", "--folder-uri", "vscode-remote://cloudenv+..." ], ``` Now the launched VS Code seems to ignore the remote URI: the resolver extension does not get activated at all. It's the same if I launch from the command-line with the exact same arguments. But if I remove the `--extensionDevelopmentPath` arg (and actually install the extension) then the resolver does get activated. Apparently it can no longer handle both at the same time. 2. Open a remote folder via a command: ``` vscode.commands.executeCommand( 'vscode.openFolder', vscode.Uri.parse('vscode-remote://cloudenv+...')); ``` Since launching a remote URI directly doesn't work, I tried first launching a local window and then opening a remote folder with a command. Then the resolver does get activated after the reload. But the debugger does not attach to it. Breakpoints in either the extension activate() method or the resolve callback don't get hit. VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.34.0-insider (693a13cd32c5be798051edc0cb43e1e39fc456d9, 2019-05-08T21:17:09.160Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.18362

title: Automatic Indentation doesn't work for single line conditionals in C/C++
Show task output automatically if there is only one task running
body: Small change in UX - if there is only one task currently running, the command will show its output automatically instead of showing a list with single task

title: Suggest install of recommended extensions after rebase

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Currently our project is sharing a `.vscode/extensions.json`. This is a great way to keep users in a project in sync on what extensions are good to use.

If I add a new extension in this file and then push to master, and another users pull's in the change, it would be cool for them to directly get a notification to install the new recommended extensions.

This works fine if the user restarts/reloads the windows, but many of us keep VS Code open for weeks without closing it. If the user could get an immediate notification after a rebase it would make life simpler.

title: Stabilize FileSearchProvider API
body:
@roblourens I created this issue in the hope `FileSearchProvider` is going to get finalized at some point. If yes, maybe add the api-finalization label here.

If I'm out of order creating this, or if I've overlooked another issue dealing with its finalization, please close.

title: Issue Reporter falls back to filing an Extension report here if extension doesn't offer a GH repo
body:
The repo for my small extension called [The Folding Stuff](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=georgejames.thefoldingstuff) is hosted on GitLab rather than GitHub. If I use Issue Reporter to try and open an issue about it my issue gets directed here (i.e. microsoft/vscode).

The same fallback behaviour occurs if I try to file against another extension of mine that doesn't declare a repo at all.

In both cases the GH issue that gets drafted doesn't mention the extension name, only its version number.

Maybe Issue Reporter should tell the user that the selected extension doesn't support filing of reports this way.

title: Issue Reporter - link to wiki page about writing good reports
body:
[This wiki page](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions) contains good guidance but I have the feeling some folk find the Report Issue option on VSCode's Help menu without also finding that wiki page.

I suggest the Issue Reporter dialog gets a link added to it.

title: Allow addition of individual files to a workspace
body:
Workspaces can currently consist of one or more folders.  

It would be great to be able to add a selection of files to the workspace, since it's not always possible to make a scenario revolve entirely around a directory.  For example, I might create a workspace for one of my git repos, but add a .gitconfig file from my profile directory.

title: autoAttachChildProcesses doesn't work when restarting
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.33.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.14.4, Windows 10

Video showcase: https://youtu.be/KpcmK2SP69I

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new folder and open it in VS Code
2. Create `index.js` with the following contents:
```javascript
const cluster = require('cluster');
const http = require('http');

if (cluster.isMaster) {
	console.log(`Master ${process.pid} is running`);

	console.log(`Forking 2 workers.`);
	// Fork workers.
	cluster.fork();
	cluster.fork();

	cluster.on('exit', (worker, code, signal) => {
		console.log(`worker ${worker.process.pid} died`);
	});
} else {
	// Workers can share any TCP connection
	// In this case it is an HTTP server
	http.createServer((req, res) => {
		res.writeHead(200);
		res.end('hello world\n');
	}).listen(8000);

	console.log(`Worker ${process.pid} started`);
}
```

3. Create `.vscode/launch.json` with the following contents:
```json
{
	"version": "0.2.0",
	"configurations": [
		{
			"type": "node",
			"request": "launch",
			"name": "Launch Program",
			"program": "${workspaceFolder}/index.js",
			"autoAttachChildProcesses": true
		}
	]
}
```
4. Start debugging `Launch Program`
5. Restart



<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Add a "Reinstall" option next to "Uninstall" that calls "Developer: Reinstall extension"

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body: There is already a "Developer: Reinstall extension" command, but we would like the "Reinstall" option added next to the "Uninstall" option in the extension context menu to make it more discoverable to users, because we still get reports of users doing uninstall/install and it's failing because they don't know they need to either run the command or restart VS Code after the uninstall. The reason our C/C++ extension requires a reinstall sometimes is if the extension enters some corrupted state (i.e. deleted/missing files). See https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-cpptools/issues/3610 as an example.

title: Terminal:`Run active file` doesn't work in remote
Add visible cues for quick pick line selection
body: When using the quick pick to access a file, you can specify which line to land on via `{file} :113`. However, there is no indication on the quickpick that this will work: Suggestion is to append ` - Line 113` in the details line (and also column if they specify `:113:10`: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35271042/57337116-142baa00-70dd-11e9-8ee3-0fbc8f5e126b.png)
